intro: Sorghum eplicatum f. dichrolepis, commonly known as the two-colored sorghum, is a botanical variant of the sorghum genus characterized by its distinctive bicoloration. This variety exhibits a unique combination of green and purple pigmentation in its leaves and stems, which is due to the presence of anthocyanin pigments. The plant is native to tropical and subtropical regions and thrives in warm climates with well-drained soils. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has also been studied for its potential in sustainable agriculture. The morphological features of this plant make it a subject of interest in both horticultural and genetic research.
